segments.text: Okay, Dr. Bain, in the fall, you will have a slightly different position at A&M.
Would you explain this, please?
Yes.
For the last four years, I've had a joint appointment of director of the Center for Energy and Mental Resources, which was created by the Board of Regents to help provide
coordinate and develop energy-related programs in teaching, research, and in public service.
That was in 1975.
In 1977, Dr. Dick Winerdi left the university for the private sector, and I took over as acting director and then director.
I've been director for the last four years.
In the fall, I will be full-time director of the center, and I will
not have my formal association with the Engineering Experiment Station as its assistant director.
I'd rather have a tie with the Engineering Experiment Station, but this was not my choosing.
But that's just the way the ball bounces.
The Energy and Mental Resources Program is, of course, very much engineering-oriented.
About $250,000 of our about-million-dollar program is in engineering, as a matter of fact.
We feel like we've helped develop engineer researchers, ag researchers, history researchers.
One of our projects in the energy side of the house is the collection of the German documents that were the records of the German synthetic fuels programs.
During World War II, Germany, not having an internal source of petroleum from natural petroleum, had to rely on synthetic fuels.
And they were producing about 3 million barrels of petroleum for lubricants and for jet fuels and that sort of thing.
That was their annual rate at that time.
No, monthly rate, I'm sorry.
monthly rate.

In this country today we use about twice that amount per day for transportation alone and we have a very serious problem because we are very dependent upon foreign producers of oil and we saw what the OPEC embargo could do to this country in 1973.
So the German documents program is one that has a lot of involvement with the history department.
It has some involvement with the technical side of the house and chemical engineers advise us and that sort of thing.
We feel that Texas A&M has a very valuable resource here for the rest of the country.

These documents contain records of problems that were experienced in the production of synthetic fuels, such as stress corrosion, hydrogen embrittlement, catalyst poisoning, and that sort of thing, that these records and their actions taken to correct their problems would be valuable to
through the new synthetic fuels industry of this country once we get going.
You think this synthetic fuels program is going to be, first thing is the finding of certain, or what is the status of it?
Well, the windfall profits tax had about $240 billion income expected over the 10-year program.
And of that, $80 billion was assigned to development of the synthetic fuels program in this country.
And $17 billion of that are now in the hands of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which is a government entity established by Congress last year.
And they are currently, I guess you would say, in the state of getting organized and having projects transferred to them from the Department of Energy.

current administration of this country is now phasing down the governmental involvement in solar and conservation and that sort of thing and feeling that the prices of energy are affecting these developments and that there's no need for the infusion of large dollars into conservation and into solar energy that if the economics are right that
people will conserve and they will develop solar energy.
What statistics do we have on whether people are conserving or not?
They are conserving.
You can see that in the use of gasoline in this country.
It's been reduced about 20%, actually.
Now, this is from conservation.
It's also from use of more efficient cars.
more fuel efficient.
The manufacturers have finally gotten the word, and Ford and General Motors are now producing lightweight cars, and in a couple of years you won't be able to buy a large car.
This is sort of forced conservation, but we need to force the conservation because, as I said, we're using close to six million barrels of liquid petroleum per day.
to run the transportation of this country alone.
We import about 7 billion barrels a day.
And that, at the prices that OPEX are charging or the world is charging, is like exporting major corporations, the wealth of our country.
It's a very serious problem.
So I'm delighted to be the director of the Center for Energy and Resources and help try to develop the resources of this state
lignite, biomass, conservation.
And so in that light, I'm delighted to be the full-time director, but I would rather stay as an assistant director part-time and help develop programs like I have in the past.
One of the recent programs I helped develop was a workshop
that is administered by the Engineering Experiment Station.
And it's a half million dollar summer program being operated right now for the Gas Research Institute out of Chicago.
We have 26 scientists.
They are physicists and chemists and engineers who are assessing the potential for developing gas supplies for this country.
from inorganic resources such as carbonates, such as water, such as carbon dioxide.
How can we develop a burnable replacement for natural gas from those resources?
And this is a program that I helped develop starting in January of this year.
It is in full force right now.
We're required to produce a final report by the 14th of August and
We have structured a program that involves a technical implementation committee and a workshop advisory panel.
And I think we've done a good job.
I hope that others feel the same way.
Other programs that I've helped develop here in engineering are, as a program developer, you have to keep your ear to the ground and locate the problems
locate the interest of what part of the federal government or what part of the industry is interested in helping to solve problems.
And I became aware of a program.
The awareness came about through my association with the American Society for Engineering Education and association with some representatives of the Department of Defense.
About four years ago, there was a program of Department of Defense that was proposed to Congress to help solve the equipment problems of universities.
Equipment is a very expensive part of a university, and maintaining modern, current, advanced capabilities is a very difficult thing.
So they had what they called a Defense Science and Engineering Equipment Program, DCEP it was called.
And from that, the Air Force set aside some monies to develop a program with industry's participation in composites.
And as a result of that, finding out the interest of the Air Force,
And having capable, competent researchers here at A&M, we were able to put the two together and develop a graduate program in composites.
That's carbon and boron fibers and that sort of thing.
Composites are, of course, lightweight replacements for metals.
And the Air Force's interest, of course, was for use in aircraft, but automobiles can be made lighter and hence more fuel efficient.
There are many applications for this.

Another program that I was involved in helping develop was a program to evaluate the behavior of oil on water in the presence of waves and in the presence of currents and in the presence of waves and currents.
That was about a million dollar program.
And from that evolved a development of an oil spill
course on how do you collect oil from water.
The American Petroleum Institute sponsored development of this course.
It was done under the Engineering Experiment Station and it was conducted a couple of times and then transferred to the Engineering Extension Service.
This is an example of the evolution of research to the teaching function and to the continuing education function.
Extension Service now teaches about 20 courses per year to industry to help industry control oil spills and to contain oil spills and that sort of thing.
We also have invited people here from the Department of Transportation.
About two years ago I sponsored a group here from
the Department of Transportation, the Coast Guard, and the Transportation Center in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
As a result of that, several people have been sponsored.
Dr. Tom Ryan and some others, Dr. John Painter in electrical engineering, have evolved a program to evaluate the global position system
as a Navy satellite to locate vessels, Coast Guard vessels in this case, more accurately than the older systems.
Dr. Don Bray in mechanical engineering has a program on rail transportation and non-destructive testing.
These kinds of research projects and programs evolved from
good relations with potential sponsors, carrying the flag of Texas A&M and helping them to know what the capabilities of A&M are.
And of course, in the final bottom line, A&M has to produce good results or they will not be in business next year.
Our good students, our graduates, of course, are worldwide now.
and the results of our research are going worldwide.
And it's an interesting dynamic atmosphere that it's just, it's been a real rewarding, a very rewarding association.
I think the Texas legislatures are doing the right thing and helping develop engineering and other research, because that is the basis for our future.
And the future economic well-being of this state and of this country depends a lot on the research that's done today for new products for tomorrow.
Dr. Bain, you said that one of the programs here that you'd like is the co-op program.
Could you discuss that briefly?
The co-op program I think is a very fine way for a young person to develop an association with an industry or with a company and help pay for his education.
I think you know or perhaps you don't know that in four and a half years a co-op student can get a degree
and pay for his degree and at the same time develop these relationships with industry and end up upon receiving his degree with a job and a long-time association with a good company.
Many of the co-ops have been involved in research programs with the Engineering Experiment Station.
When I was head of our space technology program here, which I was until about the 1950s,
We employed co-op students in our flight mechanics laboratory and in our wind tunnel program and in several of our other aerospace research programs.
We have done evaluation of some of the thermal protective tiles for the space shuttle.
That's where you, the one on the top shelf up there.
You shoot
small projectiles at those tiles to simulate the impact of insulation as the shuttle takes off.
Co-ops were involved in that.
The co-op student, he just develops a real sense of the purpose of industry, of the company that he's working for, and the importance of doing good engineering.
Then he comes back to school, and he goes to school for another semester, and then he goes back to work again.
And he comes back in the summer program, and he has to go full-time, work, study, work, study, for four and a half years.
But when he gets out, he's a real engineer.
This program, of course, is now university-wide.
It went from engineering under Dr. McGuire, Dean McGuire.
He didn't have his doctorate.
What was his first name?
Mickey.
John.
John McGuire.
M.C.
or M.A.C.?
M.C.
McGuire.
He was the assistant dean for engineering until he retired here about three years ago.
He developed the co-op program here in engineering, which then evolved to agriculture, then it evolved to science, and now it's University of Lyon.
He did a beautiful job.
Could you tell us something briefly, Dr. Payne, about the quality of the engineering student as a whole since you've been here for the last 10 years?
Have you seen any changes in the quality?
Has the quality gone down, up, or stayed about the same?
Well, I think the quality of the students has gone up.
I hope the quality of our education can stay up.
How selective are you in recruiting students into engineering?

well of course that's on the academic side of the house and that's their responsibility but the requirements for entry have been increased the sat score is now i've forgotten what it is but it's gone up from in the last 10 years as part of being more selective of the students coming in and of course also as part of some effort to maintain a top limit on
engineering enrollment.
I've seen engineering enrollment go from 3,000 students to above 11,000 students.
And this next fall, it's expected to be about 12,000 students.
The quality of the students is good.
The SAT requirements have gone up.
A number of students come here to take engineering because they hear that A&M is a tough school.
They want the challenge of a tough education.
They also come here because their daddies were Aggies.
They come here because they hear good things about A&M graduates.
They hear about the Aggie spirit.
They hear about the professionalism of professional engineers.
They hear about the fact that they can get a job.
Graduates of A&M and the College of Engineering have no problem whatsoever in having a choice, usually,
This job or that job, they have several offers, most many of them do.
And their salaries are good.
So I think that young people are accepting the challenges of a tough education.
They're dynamic.
They've got many problems yet to be solved in this world.
We old folks haven't solved them all.
There'll be plenty of problems around in the future to be solved.
I just think the quality of the graduates is great.
Otherwise, industry wouldn't come here.
What about the large number of foreign students coming here?
What do you think motivates them to come here?
The same reasons?
The reasonableness of the cost of education.
The same reasons.
You're right.
We have a large number of foreign students.
There's a problem there.
They don't pay the full cost of their education.
We are a state university.
We are paying part of the cost of educating every student that goes through here.
So you can say that the taxpayer is helping to pay for the education of foreign students.
Now, that's not to say that foreign students are not making contributions to this country, because they are.
Many of our leading scientists are foreign students.
And let's face it, our ancestors at one time came from another country.
So at one time we were farm students in that trailer.
But it is a problem because of the financing requirements.
How do you pay for the education of these people?
We're paying for it.
Is there anything else that we need to touch on that we have on?
No, I'll just say that I believe that A&M is great.
I believe that carrying the flag of Texas A&M to the Washington seat and to industry is a very gratifying job.

I think that whoever is assigned as assistant director for program development in the future I hope has got the kinds of background and experiences with the government and with industry and with the research and development.
I hope he has had a background of experience in research and development.
and that he can help bring great things to this university and the total system.
Well, Dr. Maynard, it's been a pleasure interviewing you, and I appreciate very much your patience and kindness.
Well, Billy, I appreciate your approach to this whole thing, and I want to wish you all the success in the world.
I think you do a good job.
Thank you.
Oh.
Oh.
Oh.
